metadata.title: Supplementary appendix Supplementary Information for 'Impact of changing case definitions for COVID-19 on the epidemic curve and transmission parameters in mainland China: a modelling study' 1 Model for changing case definition for the COVID-19 outbreak in China ........... 2 1.1 Overview ............................................................................................................... 2

body_text.text: There were 7 versions of the case definitions applied during the COVID-19 epidemic in China from January to March 2020. For 3 changes of versions, version 1 to 2, version 2 to 4 and version 4 to 5, there were relevant changes in the case definitions that would change the proportion of all infections identified as confirmed cases. We aim to explore the impact of these changes on the epidemic curve.

We use an exponential growth rate model for the incidence of cases by date of where + 0 is January 23, 2020, the starting date of intervention in China, * " and * "C are the rates of exponential growth and decay before and after January 23, 2020 respectively. 1 "23 (. ) is the cumulative density of the incubation period distribution. + 6 , + 7 and + 8 are the date of changing case definition from version 1 to 2, version 2 to 4 and version 4 to 5, respectively. + @ is the duration of backfill period. 5 6 , 5 7 and 5 8 are the effect of changing case definition from version 1 to 2, version 2 to 4 and version 4 to 5, respectively. 1 ;<= (. ) is the cumulative density function of the distribution of onset to reporting intervals.

We assume the lag of effect of intervention on the epidemic curve by onset was determined by the cumulative distribution of the incubation period. It is because if an intervention is to prevent transmission of infections, then after one day, the impact on the symptom onset of day 1 after intervention can be observed in infected cases with an incubation period of ≤1 day. For day 2 after intervention, the impact would be on those with an incubation period of ≤2 days, and so on.
Therefore, for t days after implementing interventions, only cases with an incubation period less than t days can be shown in the epidemic curve by onset.
Therefore the impact of intervention would be proportional to the cumulative density of incubation period.

When changing the case definition, there could be a backfill of cases that fulfilled the new case definition around the change time. We allowed for backfill up to 10 days before each change in case definitions by assuming that a change in case definitions may have a partial effect on incidence before the change date t. For each day k before the change date t, this partial effect was assumed to be the probability that the cases at day k would be reported at or after the change date t. We assumed this onset-to-reporting distribution followed a Gamma distribution and inferred this distribution from the time series of onset and reporting in China by using the convolution of the symptom onset time series and the onset-to-reporting distribution to compute the expected number of reported cases for each day in the epidemic.
We also compute the expected number of reporting cases for China F # as follows:

Based on Section 1.2, we could compute the expected epidemic curve from the model. We linked the logarithm of expected and observed epidemic curve by a normal distribution. We also linked the logarithm of expected and observed reported case number by a normal distribution.
For the parameter that only take positive value, we use a vague Uniform(0,10)

prior. Otherwise, we use a vague Uniform(-10,10) prior. For incubation period, we used the estimated incubation period with mean 5.2 days, with lognormal distribution with mean 1.43 and standard deviation 0.66 in logarithm scale (1).
We used a standard Metropolis-Hastings algorithm to update the model parameters (2) . The algorithm runs for 20000 iterations after a burn-in of 10000
iterations. Converge is visually assessed. One run takes about 20 mins on our typical desktop computer.

The fitted epidemic curve and the observed case numbers of onset for the three regions were plotted in Figure 2 . The expected case numbers were close to the observed one, suggesting that the model fit was adequate.

We estimated the number of cases that would have been identified if version 5 had been applied throughout the outbreak. In each MCMC step, we computed the number of cases by adding the estimated parameters for the effect of changing case definitions to the whole epidemics, instead of only adding them after the change of case definitions in reality. Hence, we presented the mean and 2.5 and 5 97.5 quantiles from the resulting distribution of number of cases if version 5 had been applied throughout the outbreak.
body_text.section: Estimation of case numbers if version 5 of case definition has been applied throughout the epidemic.

body_text.text: The data and computer code (in R languages) for conducting the data analysis can be downloaded from https://github.com/timktsang/covid19_casedef.

TABREF0.text: Richardson S, Spiegelhalter D. Markov Chain Monte Carlo in Practice. London: Chapman & Hall; 1996. Table S1. Definitions of suspected and confirmed cases of COVID-19 in seven versions of the National Guideline for Diagnosis and Treatment of the Novel Coronavirus Infection implemented in China since 15 January 2020.

TABREF1.text: Reduced or normal white blood cell count, or reduced lymphocyte count during the early stage of the illness; After initiation of a standard antimicrobial treatment (following the "Guidelines for the Diagnosis and Treatment of Community-acquired Pneumonia in Chinese Adults (2016 Edition)" issued by Chinese Thoracic Society and the "Guidelines for the Diagnosis and Treatment of Community-acquired Pneumonia in Children (2019 Edition)" issued by National Health Commission) for 3 days, the patient's clinical conditions had not been significantly improved or become deteriorated. Confirmed case: A medically observed case has viruses isolated from respiratory specimens (sputum, throat swab, etc.) showing high homology with a known novel coronavirus by the whole genome sequencing.

TABREF4.text: A clinically diagnosed case or suspected case with one of the following etiological confirmations: 1. Respiratory or blood specimens tested positive for the nucleic acid of SARS-CoV-2 by the real-time fluorescent RT-PCR; 2. Viruses isolated from respiratory or blood specimens showing high homology with a known SARS-CoV-2 by whole genome sequencing.
